hints.content:
A dilation by a scale factor of $\goldD{\dfrac14}$ means that all the distances in the image are $\dfrac14$ as long as they were in the pre-image. We don't have exact measurements, but that's less than half of the lengths in the pre-image.

Also, each point in the image lies on the line connecting its corresponding point in the pre-image and the center of dilation $P$. Since $\goldD{\dfrac14}<\dfrac12$, the point in the image should lie *between* the two points, and *closer to $P$* than to the pre-image.

These two options have lengths that are shorter than half the lengths in the pre-image.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/92936348f800b9a2bdd36a7cea980f9aaeb2543d) ![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3f2dce51e381b8fca518513f560f7d44b6ec238a)

Out of these two, only the first option has the image points lying between their pre-image and $P$.
Our scale factor of $\dfrac{1}{4}$ is closer to $0$ than to $1$, so every point in the image will be closer to our center $P$ than to its corresponding point in the pre-image.
